text.p: Leading stories in the Greek press:
ELEFTHEROTYPIA
--Main opposition New Democracy party true to its pre-election pledge and finds work to do. Flurry of activity and proposals on leadership vacuum continues.
--Tax department uncovers billions in unpaid taxes in investigation of BP.
TA NEA

--Miltiades Evert appears determined to re-contest leadership of New Democracy, bringing field to four candidates. Proposal for deputy president Ioannis Varvitsiotis to play interim leader role sinks.
ELEFTHEROS TYPOS
--More than 70 New Democracy cadres support an Evert re-election.
ETHNOS

--Enormous scam by multinational BP, which is alleged to have concealed 15 billion drachmas in profits over 1991-1993. Tax department throws the book at them, in what is one of the biggest cases of tax evasion ever.
--Former assistant secretary of state Richard Holbrooke to mediate for the US on issues in the Aegean and Cyprus.
KATHIMERINI
--Economy and finance ministry meeting today to examine course of current budget and set targets for 1997 budget.

--The deadlock in the opposition New Democracy takes hold as the protagonists in the leadership battle appear unwilling to give ground on any issue. Resigned leader Miltiades Evert still considering whether to contest the leadership.
--Commercial Bank considering voluntary resignation incentives for highly-paid employees in effort to cut back on operating expenses and wage bills.
--National Bank prepares immediate steps to bolster market position: priority the review of the bank's bond loan and preparing the ground with mutual fund firms to increase share capital.
IMERISIA
--BP slapped with fine of 7.5 billion drachmas by finance ministry, following three years of alleged tax evasion.
--Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou chairs meeting today on budget, the first in a series, to examine priorities and pending issues.
KERDOS
--Increased liquidity in the economy in August, Bank of Greece says. Both M3 money supply and M4 monetary aggregate rises slightly.
--Concerns about how to satisfy election promises as costing shows readjustment of farmers' pensions to total 40 billion drachmas.
--Bourse general price index is being reformed to become more representative of market trends.

--Interest rates stable for new T-bills issue set for month's end. Foreign and smaller Greek banks continue to be displeased with exclusion from private placement of new bonds by finance ministry on Wednesday.
--Could over the future of another two insurance firms.
EXPRESS
--Alarm bells go off over the budget. Fiscal policy at the epicentre of prepartions of government's economic policy statements in Parliament and the drafting of the 1997 state budget.
--Liquidity contained in August.
--European Commission to ask government for clarifications on state grants of over 10 billion drachmas to "Drapetsona Fertilisers" and AEBAL.
NAFTEMBORIKI
--Finance ministry sources say changes to objective tax criteria system are in the pipeline.
--All state utilities (DEKO) to be limited liability companies by the end of the year. National economy ministry circular calls for prompt response by boards to provisions of Community law.
--Credit Agricole buys 11.5 percent of Aspis Pronia.
